Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of muscle makes up the muscular system?
Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of muscles in the human body? Options: A. 200, B. 650, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary function of the muscular system. Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To facilitate the movement of the body, C. To control the nervous system, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient has a muscle injury in their arm, and their doctor advises them to avoid heavy lifting. Which type of muscle contraction is most relevant to this scenario? Options: A. Shortening muscle fibers, B. Lengthening muscle fibers, C. Stabilizing force, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between skeletal muscles and the somatic nervous system. What can be inferred about their connection? Options: A. Skeletal muscles are controlled by the autonomic nervous system, B. Skeletal muscles have no connection to the nervous system, C. Skeletal muscles are connected to the somatic nervous system, allowing for almost complete control over their movements, D. Skeletal muscles are only connected to the somatic nervous system during sleep Correct Option: C
Question 5: Compare and contrast fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers. What is the primary difference between them? Options: A. Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly, B. Fast-twitch fibers are endurance cells, while slow-twitch fibers tire quickly, C. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly but tire quickly, while slow-twitch fibers react slowly and are endurance cells, D. Fast-twitch fibers are only found in the legs, while slow-twitch fibers are only found in the back Correct Option: C
Question 6: Evaluate the importance of the muscular system in maintaining body temperature. What percentage of body warmth is provided by muscles? Options: A. 20%, B. 50%, C. 85%, D. 100% Correct Option: C
Question 7: Synthesize the information about the muscular system and its role in movement. What would happen if the muscular system failed to function properly? Options: A. The body would be able to move normally, B. The body would be unable to regulate its temperature, C. The body would be unable to move or maintain posture, D. The body would only be able to move its skeletal muscles Correct Option: C
Question 8: Apply the knowledge about the muscular system to a real-world scenario. A sprinter wants to improve their performance. What type of muscle fibers should they focus on developing? Options: A. Slow-twitch fibers, B. Fast-twitch fibers, C. Both slow-twitch and fast-twitch fibers, D. Neither slow-twitch nor fast-twitch fibers Correct Option: B
Question 9: Identify the type of muscle that lines the blood vessels and certain organs, such as the intestine and uterus. Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Adipose tissue Correct Option: C
Question 10: Justify the statement that the muscular system is "largely invisible to us." What does this mean in the context of the transcript? Options: A. The muscular system is invisible because it is not important, B. The muscular system is invisible because it is not visible to the naked eye, C. The muscular system is invisible because we often take its functions for granted, D. The muscular system is invisible because it only works at night Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 9: Identify the type of muscle that lines the blood vessels and certain organs, such as the intestine and uterus. Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Adipose tissue Correct Option: C**

However, this question only partially matches the ground truth MCQ, as it only asks about smooth muscle, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about all three types of muscles.

A more accurate match would be a question that asks about the composition of the muscular system, including all three types of muscles. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the closest match, I would say that **none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ**. However, if I had to choose the closest one, I would say that **Question 9** is the closest, but it's not a perfect match.

To provide a more accurate answer, I would say that the generated MCQs are missing a question that asks about the composition of the muscular system, including all three types of muscles. If such a question existed, it would be the closest match to the ground truth MCQ.

In this case, I would recommend creating a new question that asks about the composition of the muscular system, including all three types of muscles, to provide a more accurate match to the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to provide an index, I would say that the closest match is **Question 9**, but please note that it's not a perfect match.

Index: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fast twitch muscle cells:
Options: A. Use energy slowly, B. Would be abundant in the muscles of a sprinter, C. Have lots of nerve cells, D. Help us to stand upright
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of muscles in the human body? Options: A. 200, B. 650, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary function of the muscular system. Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To facilitate the movement of the body, C. To control the nervous system, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient has a muscle injury in their arm, and their doctor advises them to avoid heavy lifting. Which type of muscle contraction is most relevant to this scenario? Options: A. Shortening muscle fibers, B. Lengthening muscle fibers, C. Stabilizing force, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between skeletal muscles and the somatic nervous system. What can be inferred about their connection? Options: A. Skeletal muscles are controlled by the autonomic nervous system, B. Skeletal muscles have no connection to the nervous system, C. Skeletal muscles are connected to the somatic nervous system, allowing for almost complete control over their movements, D. Skeletal muscles are only connected to the somatic nervous system during sleep Correct Option: C
Question 5: Compare and contrast fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers. What is the primary difference between them? Options: A. Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly, B. Fast-twitch fibers are endurance cells, while slow-twitch fibers tire quickly, C. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly but tire quickly, while slow-twitch fibers react slowly and are endurance cells, D. Fast-twitch fibers are only found in the legs, while slow-twitch fibers are only found in the back Correct Option: C
Question 6: Evaluate the importance of the muscular system in maintaining body temperature. What percentage of body warmth is provided by muscles? Options: A. 20%, B. 50%, C. 85%, D. 100% Correct Option: C
Question 7: Synthesize the information about the muscular system and its role in movement. What would happen if the muscular system failed to function properly? Options: A. The body would be able to move normally, B. The body would be unable to regulate its temperature, C. The body would be unable to move or maintain posture, D. The body would only be able to move its skeletal muscles Correct Option: C
Question 8: Apply the knowledge about the muscular system to a real-world scenario. A sprinter wants to improve their performance. What type of muscle fibers should they focus on developing? Options: A. Slow-twitch fibers, B. Fast-twitch fibers, C. Both slow-twitch and fast-twitch fibers, D. Neither slow-twitch nor fast-twitch fibers Correct Option: B
Question 9: Identify the type of muscle that lines the blood vessels and certain organs, such as the intestine and uterus. Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Adipose tissue Correct Option: C
Question 10: Justify the statement that the muscular system is "largely invisible to us." What does this mean in the context of the transcript? Options: A. The muscular system is invisible because it is not important, B. The muscular system is invisible because it is not visible to the naked eye, C. The muscular system is invisible because we often take its functions for granted, D. The muscular system is invisible because it only works at night Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One type of muscle contraction results in a stabilizing force. This:
Options: A. Enables us to stand and sit upright, B. Means it helps us to lift heavy things, C. Makes the muscle very tense
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of muscles in the human body? Options: A. 200, B. 650, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary function of the muscular system. Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To facilitate the movement of the body, C. To control the nervous system, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient has a muscle injury in their arm, and their doctor advises them to avoid heavy lifting. Which type of muscle contraction is most relevant to this scenario? Options: A. Question 4: Analyze the relationship between skeletal muscles and the somatic nervous system. What can be inferred about their connection? Options: A. Skeletal muscles are connected to the somatic nervous system, allowing for almost complete control over their movements, D. Skeletal muscles are only connected to the somatic nervous system during sleep Correct Option: C
Question 5: Compare and contrast fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers. What is the primary difference between them? Options: A. the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines

made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from

the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed

or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains

may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What proportion of the body’s weight does the skeletal system make up?
Options: A. 40 percent, B. 30 percent, C. 75 percent, D. 30 to 40 percent
Correct Option: D

The body would be able to move normally, B. The body would be unable to regulate its temperature, C. The body would be unable to move or maintain posture, D. The body would only be able to move its skeletal muscles Correct Option: C
Question 8: Apply the knowledge about the muscular system to a real-world scenario. A sprinter wants to improve their performance. What type of muscle fibers should they focus on developing? Options: A. Slow-twitch fibers, B. Fast-twitch fibers, C. Both slow-twitch and fast-twitch fibers, D. Neither slow-twitch nor fast-twitch fibers Correct Option: B
Question 9: Identify the type of muscle that lines the blood vessels and certain organs, such as the intestine and uterus. Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Adipose tissue Correct Option: C

The muscular system is invisible because it is not important, B. The muscular system is invisible because it is not visible to the naked eye, C. The muscular system is invisible because we often take its functions for granted, D. The muscular system is invisible because it only works at night Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Without the muscular system, we wouldn’t be able to make most of the body heat that we require.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate number of muscles in the human body? Options: A. 200, B. 650, C. 1000, D. 2000 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary function of the muscular system. Options: A. To regulate body temperature, B. To facilitate the movement of the body, C. To control the nervous system, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient has a muscle injury in their arm, and their doctor advises them to avoid heavy lifting. Which type of muscle contraction is most relevant to this scenario? Options: A. Shortening muscle fibers, B. Lengthening muscle fibers, C. Stabilizing force, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between skeletal muscles and the somatic nervous system. What can be inferred about their connection? Options: A. Skeletal muscles are controlled by the autonomic nervous system, B. Skeletal muscles have no connection to the nervous system, C. Skeletal muscles are connected to the somatic nervous system, allowing for almost complete control over their movements, D. Skeletal muscles are only connected to the somatic nervous system during sleep Correct Option: C
Question 5: Compare and contrast fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers. What is the primary difference between them? Options: A. Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly, B. Fast-twitch fibers are endurance cells, while slow-twitch fibers tire quickly, C. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly but tire quickly, while slow-twitch fibers react slowly and are endurance cells, D. Fast-twitch fibers are only found in the legs, while slow-twitch fibers are only found in the back Correct Option: C
Question 6: Evaluate the importance of the muscular system in maintaining body temperature. What percentage of body warmth is provided by muscles? Options: A. 20%, B. 50%, C. 85%, D. 100% Correct Option: C
Question 7: Synthesize the information about the muscular system and its role in movement. What would happen if the muscular system failed to function properly? Options: A. The body would be able to move normally, B. The body would be unable to regulate its temperature, C. The body would be unable to move or maintain posture, D. The body would only be able to move its skeletal muscles Correct Option: C
Question 8: Apply the knowledge about the muscular system to a real-world scenario. A sprinter wants to improve their performance. What type of muscle fibers should they focus on developing? Options: A. Slow-twitch fibers, B. Fast-twitch fibers, C. Both slow-twitch and fast-twitch fibers, D. Neither slow-twitch nor fast-twitch fibers Correct Option: B
Question 9: Identify the type of muscle that lines the blood vessels and certain organs, such as the intestine and uterus. Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Adipose tissue Correct Option: C
Question 10: Justify the statement that the muscular system is "largely invisible to us." What does this mean in the context of the transcript? Options: A. The muscular system is invisible because it is not important, B. The muscular system is invisible because it is not visible to the naked eye, C. The muscular system is invisible because we often take its functions for granted, D. The muscular system is invisible because it only works at night Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question evaluates the importance of the muscular system in maintaining body temperature, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ. The options provided in Question 6 also allow for a direct comparison with the ground truth MCQ, as the correct answer (C. 85%) supports the statement made in the ground truth MCQ that the muscular system is responsible for generating most of the body heat required for survival.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists discovered that the cyclops sheep deformity was caused by pregnant ewes eating:
Options: A. Grass, B. Berries, C. Wild corn lilies, D. Fruit flies
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers from the U.S. Department of Agriculture regarding the cause of the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous birth defect-causing plants., B. The sheep had a genetic mutation., C. The sheep had been exposed to radiation., D. The sheep had a viral infection. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name given to the active molecule found in wild corn lilies that caused the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. Cyclopamine, B. Hedgehog protein, C. Smoothened protein, D. Patched protein Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the result of Professor Philip Beachy's lab turning off the hedgehog genes in mice? Options: A. The mice developed severe defects in their brains, organs, and eyes., B. The mice developed normally with no defects., C. The mice developed minor defects in their brains and organs., D. The mice developed only eye defects. Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does the hedgehog gene communicate its directives to cells? Options: A. Through the release of a protein that binds to DNA, B. Through the release of a protein that kicks off a complex series of cellular signals, C. Through the release of a hormone that stimulates cell growth, D. Through the release of a molecule that inhibits cell division Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the patched protein in the hedgehog signaling pathway? Options: A. To inhibit the smoothened protein, B. To activate the smoothened protein, C. To bind to the hedgehog protein, D. To release the smoothened protein Correct Option: A
Question 6: A farmer notices that some of his sheep are giving birth to lambs with a singular deformity, similar to the cyclops sheep. What would be the most likely cause of this deformity? Options: A. A genetic mutation, B. Exposure to a poisonous plant, C. A viral infection, D. Radiation exposure Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclops Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not suitable as a treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome? Options: A. It was not effective in treating the cancers, B. It caused negative side effects and had difficult chemical properties, C. It was too expensive to produce, D. It was not approved by regulatory agencies Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the outcome of the research into the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The discovery of a new species of sheep, B. The development of a new treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, C. The identification of a new genetic mutation, D. The understanding of a complex signaling pathway and the development of new cancer treatments Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main lesson that can be learned from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always the cause of birth defects, B. That sometimes there is more to a mystery than meets the eye, C. That scientists should always give up when faced with a difficult problem, D. That research into animal deformities is a waste of time Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the likely cause of a deformity in sheep similar to the cyclops sheep. The correct option, "Exposure to a poisonous plant", is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Wild corn lilies". The other options in Question 6 are also plausible but incorrect, similar to the options in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6.

a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Two scientists won the Nobel Prize for the discovery of the hedgehog gene. Why did they choose that name?
Options: A. The gene is only found in hedgehogs, B. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on fruit flies’ bodies, C. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on mice, D. The gene was first discovered in hedgehogs
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers from the U.S. Department of Agriculture regarding the cause of the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous birth defect-causing plants., B. The sheep had a genetic mutation., C. The sheep had been exposed to radiation., D. The sheep had a viral infection. Correct Option: A

Question 3: What was the result of Professor Philip Beachy's lab turning off the hedgehog genes in mice? Options: A. The mice developed severe defects in their brains, organs, and eyes., B. The mice developed normally with no defects., C. The mice developed minor defects in their brains and organs., D. The mice developed only eye defects. Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does the hedgehog gene communicate its directives to cells? Options: A. Through the release of a protein that binds to DNA, B. Through the release of a protein that kicks off a complex series of cellular signals, C. Through the release of a hormone that stimulates cell growth, D. Through the release of a molecule that inhibits cell division Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the patched protein in the hedgehog signaling pathway? Options: A. To inhibit the smoothened protein, B. To activate the smoothened protein, C. To bind to the hedgehog protein, D. To release the smoothened protein Correct Option: A
Question 6: A farmer notices that some of his sheep are giving birth to lambs with a singular deformity, similar to the cyclops sheep. What would be the most likely cause of this deformity? Options: A. A genetic mutation, B. Exposure to a poisonous plant, C. A viral infection, D. Radiation exposure Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclops Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not suitable as a treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome? Options: A. It was not effective in treating the cancers, B. It caused negative side effects and had difficult chemical properties, C. It was too expensive to produce, D. It was not approved by regulatory agencies Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the outcome of the research into the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The discovery of a new species of sheep, B. The development of a new treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, C. The identification of a new genetic mutation, D. The understanding of a complex signaling pathway and the development of new cancer treatments Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main lesson that can be learned from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always the cause of birth defects, B. That sometimes there is more to a mystery than meets the eye, C. That scientists should always give up when faced with a difficult problem, D. That research into animal deformities is a waste of time Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it deals with how genes communicate their directives to cells. Although the wording is different, the intent of both questions is similar, focusing on the role of genes in cellular processes.

Here's the generated MCQ 4 for reference:
Question 4: How does the hedgehog gene communicate its directives to cells? 
Options: A. Through the release of a protein that binds to DNA, B. Through the release of a protein that kicks off a complex series of cellular signals, C. Through the release of a hormone that stimulates cell growth, D. Through the release of a molecule that inhibits cell division 
Correct Option: B

This question is the closest match to the ground truth MCQ, which asks, "What do genes do?" with the correct option being "Tells the cells what to do and when to do it."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In healthy cells, the hedgehog protein latches onto:
Options: A. The smoothened protein, B. The patched protein, C. Cyclopamine, D. The hedgehog gene
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers from the U.S. Department of Agriculture regarding the cause of the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous birth defect-causing plants., B. The sheep had a genetic mutation., C. The sheep had been exposed to radiation., D. The sheep had a viral infection. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name given to the active molecule found in wild corn lilies that caused the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. Cyclopamine, B. Hedgehog protein, C. Smoothened protein, D. Patched protein Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the result of Professor Philip Beachy's lab turning off the hedgehog genes in mice? Options: A. The mice developed severe defects in their brains, organs, and eyes., B. The mice developed normally with no defects., C. The mice developed minor defects in their brains and organs., D. The mice developed only eye defects. Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does the hedgehog gene communicate its directives to cells? Options: A. Through the release of a protein that binds to DNA, B. Through the release of a protein that kicks off a complex series of cellular signals, C. Through the release of a hormone that stimulates cell growth, D. Through the release of a molecule that inhibits cell division Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the role of the patched protein in the hedgehog signaling pathway? Options: A. To inhibit the smoothened protein, B. To activate the smoothened protein, C. To bind to the hedgehog protein, D. To release the smoothened protein Correct Option: A
Question 6: A farmer notices that some of his sheep are giving birth to lambs with a singular deformity, similar to the cyclops sheep. What would be the most likely cause of this deformity? Options: A. A genetic mutation, B. Exposure to a poisonous plant, C. A viral infection, D. Radiation exposure Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclops Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not suitable as a treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome? Options: A. It was not effective in treating the cancers, B. It caused negative side effects and had difficult chemical properties, C. It was too expensive to produce, D. It was not approved by regulatory agencies Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the outcome of the research into the cyclops sheep deformity? Options: A. The discovery of a new species of sheep, B. The development of a new treatment for cancers associated with Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, C. The identification of a new genetic mutation, D. The understanding of a complex signaling pathway and the development of new cancer treatments Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main lesson that can be learned from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always the cause of birth defects, B. That sometimes there is more to a mystery than meets the eye, C. That scientists should always give up when faced with a difficult problem, D. That research into animal deformities is a waste of time Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the role of a specific protein in the hedgehog signaling pathway. The options for Question 5 also match the content of the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (A) stating that the patched protein inhibits the smoothened protein, which is equivalent to the correct option (B) in the ground truth MCQ stating that the hedgehog protein latches onto the patched protein.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous

and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided

with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly

a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating

in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy

involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell

make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely

in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Lung cancer, B. Brain cancer, C. Colon cancer, D. Skin cancer
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Our distant ancestors counted objects using:
Options: A. Tally marks, B. Roman numerals, C. Fingers and toes, D. Fractions
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method did our distant ancestors use to count objects? Options: A. Simple arithmetic, B. Tally marks, C. Fractions, D. Geometry Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who is credited with discovering irrational numbers in Ancient Greece? Options: A. Pythagoras, B. Hippasus, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century? Options: A. They were too complex for merchants to understand, B. They were easier to forge or alter, and less familiar to customers, C. They were only used for mathematical equations, D. They were not compatible with Roman numerals Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the impact of the concept of zero on record keeping in the Middle Ages? Options: A. It made record keeping more secure and reliable, B. It opened the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt, C. It made calculations more time-consuming, D. It had no significant impact Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did some mathematicians, like Gerolamo Cardano, avoid using zero in their work? Options: A. They did not understand its concept, B. They thought it was too complex to use, C. They believed it would have made their work less accurate, D. They wanted to avoid controversy surrounding its use Correct Option: D
Question 6: What type of information can be translated into a string of numbers, making it potentially illegal to possess or publish? Options: A. Only copyrighted materials, B. Only proprietary materials, C. Only state secrets, D. Any information, including text, image, video, or executable programs Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the significance of the large prime number shared and distributed in 2001? Options: A. It was a new mathematical discovery, B. It was a code that could be used to decrypt DVDs, C. It was a solution to a complex mathematical equation, D. It was a random number with no significance Correct Option: B
Question 8: How do governments sometimes restrict the use of certain numbers? Options: A. By banning their use in mathematical equations, B. By prohibiting their display due to symbolic meaning, C. By restricting their use in record keeping, D. By making them illegal to possess or publish Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main idea behind the concept of "illegal numbers"? Options: A. That certain numbers are too complex to use, B. That certain numbers have symbolic meaning and can be used to represent protected information, C. That certain numbers are too large to calculate, D. That certain numbers are too small to be significant Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the mathematician's pencil in today's world? Options: A. It is becoming less relevant due to technology, B. It is only used for simple calculations, C. It is growing stronger by the day as calculations and algorithms shape more of our lives, D. It is only used for mathematical equations Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

The ground truth MCQ asks about the method used by our distant ancestors to count objects, and the correct option is "tally marks." Question 1 asks a similar question, with the correct option also being "tally marks." The question content, options, and overall intent are similar between the two MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a rational number?
Options: A. The length of the diagonal of a square with side-length of 1, B. A number that cannot be expressed as the ratio of two quantities, C. A perfect number, D. A number that can be expressed as a ratio of two quantities
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method did our distant ancestors use to count objects? Options: A. Simple arithmetic, B. Tally marks, C. Fractions, D. Geometry Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who is credited with discovering irrational numbers in Ancient Greece? Options: A. Pythagoras, B. Hippasus, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century? Options: A. They were too complex for merchants to understand, B. They were easier to forge or alter, and less familiar to customers, C. They were only used for mathematical equations, D. They were not compatible with Roman numerals Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the impact of the concept of zero on record keeping in the Middle Ages? Options: A. It made record keeping more secure and reliable, B. It opened the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt, C. It made calculations more time-consuming, D. It had no significant impact Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did some mathematicians, like Gerolamo Cardano, avoid using zero in their work? Options: A. They did not understand its concept, B. They thought it was too complex to use, C. They believed it would have made their work less accurate, D. They wanted to avoid controversy surrounding its use Correct Option: D
Question 6: What type of information can be translated into a string of numbers, making it potentially illegal to possess or publish? Options: A. Only copyrighted materials, B. Only proprietary materials, C. Only state secrets, D. Any information, including text, image, video, or executable programs Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the significance of the large prime number shared and distributed in 2001? Options: A. It was a new mathematical discovery, B. It was a code that could be used to decrypt DVDs, C. It was a solution to a complex mathematical equation, D. It was a random number with no significance Correct Option: B
Question 8: How do governments sometimes restrict the use of certain numbers? Options: A. By banning their use in mathematical equations, B. By prohibiting their display due to symbolic meaning, C. By restricting their use in record keeping, D. By making them illegal to possess or publish Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main idea behind the concept of "illegal numbers"? Options: A. That certain numbers are too complex to use, B. That certain numbers have symbolic meaning and can be used to represent protected information, C. That certain numbers are too large to calculate, D. That certain numbers are too small to be significant Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the mathematician's pencil in today's world? Options: A. It is becoming less relevant due to technology, B. It is only used for simple calculations, C. It is growing stronger by the day as calculations and algorithms shape more of our lives, D. It is only used for mathematical equations Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who were the Pythagoreans?
Options: A. People who discovered and proved the Pythagorean theorem, B. Merchants and bankers who used Pythagoras’ mathematics, C. Mathematician-philosophers who were members of Pythagoras’ school, D. Ancient Greeks who studied mathematics
Correct Option: C

It was a code that could be used to decrypt DVDs, C. It was a solution to a complex mathematical equation, D. It was a random number with no significance Correct Option: B

They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

Question: Why were Arabic numerals banned for record-keeping in Florence?
Options: A. Because they were unfamiliar to most people, B. Because they were not useful, C. Because they were illegible, D. Because they were regarded as easy to adjust fraudulently
Correct Option: D
